> Have you really never tried to work your way through a mess of JavaDoc
> with no easy way to figure out what classes you needed and what you
> could ignore?

Yes, I have. I think it could have been avoided by better packaging. In
fact, as Robert already pointed out, it's easy to exclude packages from
JavaDoc.

> Has it been that long since you learned a new API?
> Featuritis isn't just a problem for applications. It applies to
> libraries too. Smaller is better. Too large an API becomes a problem.

If I find a package with the name "internal" in it, I'd never come to the
conclusion that it is one I should look at.

> Trying to bring this back on topic, the JUnit 3.8 API is a good
> example. It's actually pretty small but not as small as it could or
> should be. Take a look at
> http://www.junit.org/junit/javadoc/3.8.1/index.htm How much of that
> does a programmer actually need to know?

Mainly the content of junit.framework. Doesn't look hard to find out to me.

> How easy is it for someone
> trying to learn the API to figure what they need to do and where to
> get started? Even experienced users can have trouble finding a
> relatively unfamiliar class, and that's a small API as APIs go, and
> much better documented than most.

I don't remember having that problem, or having it seen mentioned on the
mailing list often.

> Probably half of what's there could
> be non-public, and users would be the better off for it if it were.
> What benefit is served by making junit.samples or TestResult$1
> public?  

I don't see the problem you seem to see. I never had a problem with the
Junit API.

Cheers, Ilja
